title: Examples UIs
narrative:
This is an overview of the various example UIs
    in the test suite.

    This specification also ensures that the
    various UI examples in the test suite, 
    run successfully and also produce
    UIs with expected state and appearance.

features.id: The advanced UI define in the examples has the expected state.

extraInfo: The advanced UI example is absolutely packed with things to see. Yet, at the same time, it is not too much code and also not too complicated. It really shows you how boilerplate code can be reduced to a minimum when using SwingTree.

blocks.text: We create the UI.

features.id: The form UI defined in the examples has the expected state.

extraInfo: The form UI looks like this: ![simple-form-UI.png](https://raw.githubusercontent.com/globaltcad/swing-tree/main/src/test/resources/snapshots/simple-form-UI.png) This is the oldest example in the test suite and also a great first example of how to write declarative UI code with SwingTree.

blocks.text: We get the UI.
We should be able to find the hover icon button and it should have the expected state.

features.id: The login example UI defined in the examples, a good MVVM demonstration.

extraInfo: The login example view, together with the login example view model, is a really basic example of how to do MVVM with SwingTree. For a more advanced example, see the user registration example.

features.id: The user registration example UI defined in the examples, a good MVVM demonstration.

extraInfo: The user registration example, together with the user registration example view model, is a more advanced example of how to do the MVVM design pattern with SwingTree. It involves a lot of input validation that is done in the view model. For a more basic example, see the login example view.

features.id: The list examples UI defined in the examples can be created.
The box shadow picker example UI defined in the examples can be created.

extraInfo: Not only is the box shadow picker example an advanced example of how to write MVVM applications with SwingTree, it is also a nice little tool that shows you how to use the SwingTree style API to override the default look and feel of Swing components.

features.id: The note guesser example UI defined in the examples can be created.

extraInfo: The guesser example view looks like this: ![note-guesser-UI.png](https://raw.githubusercontent.com/globaltcad/swing-tree/main/src/test/resources/snapshots/note-guesser-UI.png) This not only demonstrates how to do some custom 2D rendering on a JPanel, it is also a nice little game you can play to test your knowledge of music theory. Just navigate to the class and run it yourself and play around with it. The view model is also a nice example of how to do MVVM with SwingTree.

extraInfo: The well rounded UI looks like this: ![well-rounded-UI.png](https://raw.githubusercontent.com/globaltcad/swing-tree/main/src/test/resources/snapshots/well-rounded-UI.png) This is the most basic example of how to use the SwingTree style API to override the default look and feel of Swing components. As you can see, the style engine of SwingTree supports shadows, rounded corners, gradients and much much more out of the box. Here we will only test looks of the UI, if you want to see the code, click here to jump to the class. And also feel free to run it yourself, it has a main method for that purpose already.
